title: Sam West
text:
Samuel Filmore West (October 5, 1904 – November 23, 1985) was a <a href="center%20fielder">center fielder</a> in <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> who played for three different teams from to . Listed at , 165 lb., West batted and threw left-handed. He was born in <a href="Longview%2C%20Texas">Longview, Texas</a>.
West entered the majors in 1927 with the <a href="Washington%20Senators%20%281901%E2%80%9360%29">Washington Senators</a>, playing six years for them before moving to the <a href="St.%20Louis%20Browns">St. Louis Browns</a> (1933–1938), again with Washington (1938–1941), and the <a href="Chicago%20White%20Sox">Chicago White Sox</a> (1942). His most productive season came in 1931 when he posted a career-high .333 <a href="batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">batting average</a> and reached career highs in slugging percentage (.481), hits (175), doubles (43), triples (13), and rbi (91). In 1933, he was selected to the first <a href="MLB%20All-Star%20Game">All-Star Game</a> ever played, being selected again in , and .
During his career, West collected a .300 average during eight seasons; led AL outfielders in <a href="putout">putout</a>s twice, <a href="double%20play">double play</a>s three times, and <a href="assist%20%28baseball%29">assist</a>s once, and four times was considered in the <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball%20Most%20Valuable%20Player%20Award">AL Most Valuable Player</a> vote. Although he played with Washington during ten seasons, he missed the <a href="American%20League">American League</a> pennant-winning team that lost the <a href="1933%20World%20Series">1933 World Series</a> to the <a href="New%20York%20Giants%20%28NL%29">New York Giants</a> after being traded to the Browns in exchange for <a href="Goose%20Goslin">Goose Goslin</a>. 
In a sixteen-season career, West was a .299 hitter (1838-for-6148) with 75 home runs and 838 <a href="run%20batted%20in">RBI</a> in 1753 <a href="games%20played">games</a>, including 934 <a href="Run%20%28baseball%29">runs</a>, 347 doubles, 101 triples, 53 stolen bases, 696 walks, a .371 <a href="on-base%20percentage">on-base percentage</a>, and a .425 slugging percentage.
Defensively, he posted a .983 <a href="fielding%20percentage">fielding percentage</a>. Following his playing career, West served in the U.S. Army during World War II. After discharge from the service, he spent three years as a <a href="coach%20%28sport%29">coach</a> with the Senators.
West died in <a href="Lubbock%2C%20Texas">Lubbock</a>, Texas at age 81.
